body.p: Option pricing models are widely used in, and accepted by, the financial markets. However, there are differences between employee share options and traded share options. The Board considered the valuation implications of these differences, with assistance from its Advisory Group and other experts, including experts in the FASB’s Option Valuation Group, and comments made by respondents to ED 2. Employee share options usually differ from traded options in the following ways, which are discussed further below:

li.p: there is a vesting period, during which time the share options are not exercisable;
there are conditions attached to vesting which, if not satisfied, cause the options to be forfeited; and
the option term is significantly longer.
